indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Number of UNV health professionals recruited to the Health Sector in Limpopo, and the extend they contribute to health service delivery
2. Quality and types of skills transferred to local health professionals and the extend they contribute to local knowledge base
3. Number of events held to promote volunteerism and the extend they impact on locals to volunteer
4. Some form of agreement between UNDP and the province starting 2014

baseline.comment: 2009:The province is largely rural with an estimated population of 5 404 868 people which constitutes 10.4 % of the South African total population. Being a rural province, the resultant brain drain creates a huge shortage of health professionals in the province as health professionals leave the province for better opportunities locally and internationally. Since January 2013, the project's number of UNV health professionals has declined from 48 to 26. The province is also characterised by poor health infrastructure which does not attract health professionals. Volunteerism by local professional is also not common in the province. The current partnership/programme with UNDP ends in 2014. The current partnership programme with UNDP ends in 2014.

target.comment: 1. The fourth partnership programme on health service delivery for Limpopo government developed to support the Provincial Department of Health in meeting health service delivery mandate 2. At least 12 new additional UNV doctors recruited and deployed across the health facilities in the Limpopo

actual.comment: UNDP Support to the Health Sector in Limpopo programme has recruited and retained 17 medical professionals to strengthen health care service delivery in the province. The Annual Performance Plan of 2013/14 reflected gradual improvement of access to health care and service volumes at district and tertiary hospitals as well as doctor-patient ratio of 16 to 100,000

target.comment: 1. Phase IV Project document developed and approved by the Department of Health in Limpopo 2. End of Phase 3 project evaluation conducted and findings used for development of Phase IV Prodoc

actual.comment: UNDP and UNV have successfully supported the implementation of the programme which continued to the recruit and place UNV health professionals to the Health Sector in Limpopo to strengthen health service delivery, more importantly to the rural communities. Though the target of recruiting and placing of 120 UNVs was not achieved, the programme with the support of the hospital management has led to the establishment of 2 diabetic clinics in Polokwane and Mankweng Hospitals. Two internal medicine specialists are each able to see between 30 and 50 patients per week. The establishment of the clinics was championed by the UNVs as a response to a high incidence of diabetes [[E18]]). The success of this partnership programme also led to the development of the Phase IV programme which started in April 2015.

iati-activity.title: Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildland fire Hazards Assoc
iati-activity.description: Develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change-induced fire hazards and risks

iati-activity.title: Reducing Disaster Risks
iati-activity.description: Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildfire Hazards Associated with Climate Change in South Africa

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
2013: 1(a). Number of Fire Protection Associations (FPAs) integrated into and aligned with, the affected structures (including the municipal land use planning, fire brigade and disaster services)
1(b) Ability of regional centers and networks with capacity to effectively respond to extreme weather events.
2. Number of Automated Weather Stations (AWS) recording local weather conditions under a changing climate regime in the high altitude mountain areas of the Fynbos biome.
3.Number of private landowners in FPAs with institutionised proactive risk management measures encouraged by insurance based incentives

baseline.comment:
2012: There is only one Fire Protection Association with inadequate capacity to manage climate-induced windland fires in the Fynbos Biome
2012: Ten automated Weather Stations are currently operational in the Fynbos Biome
2012: Ten private landowners taking proactive risk management measures to prevent wildfire and associated hazard reduction

target.comment: 1. Capacity building programme at local level developed to manage incidents and extent of fires 2. Risk Management system for fire management improved 3. Risk reductions interventions implemented

actual.comment: Capacity building programme was developed at local level to manage incidents and extent of fires Risk Management systems were established to improve management of incidents and fire.

target.comment: â€¢ Fire Protection Association (FPAs) in two demonstration sites- Overberg and Cape Winelands District Municipalities established â€¢ Skills and competency levels of FPA members and fire practitioners in Integrated Fire Management (IFM) developed. â€¢ Prospective funding sources and other mechanisms identified to ensure finance sustainability of FPAs in the long term. â€¢ Communication and awareness strategy for the FPAs, United Fire Protection Association (UFPAs) and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)implemented â€¢ Test the Fire Protection Management toolbox in Matatiele and Cacadu Districts, respectively

actual.comment: Due to patterns of urbanisation, agriculture and potential impact upon water catchment areas, Fynbos Biome is identified as the most vulnerable region in South Africa with respect to disaster risks from Wildland fire. UNDP/GEF Special Climate Change Fund supported Department of Environmental Affairs to develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change induced fire hazards and risks through building capacity at local level to manage increased incidence and extent of fires. Six Fire Protection Associations (FPAs) and local authorities, and 1547 stakeholders were trained in integrated fire management in the Fynbos biome of the Western Cape. Two FPAs were established in Overberg and Cape Winelands District Municipalities; a Fire Protection Toolkit and FPA handbook to document best practices in coordinated Integrated Fire management (IFM) implementation, have been produced. Six Advanced Fire Systems (AFIS) terminals have been installed across the Fynbos Biome to enhance fire monitoring and prediction. 50 Automated Weather Stations also installed across the biome to measure local weather conditions [[E11]].

result.title: Objective
result.description: Develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change-induced fire hazards and risks.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Increased number and extent (ha) of non-damaging wildfires (i.e. Ã¢â‚¬ËœminorÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and Ã¢â‚¬ËœinsignificantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ fires, as described in section 2.5) per annum in the Fynbos Biome
Decreased number and extent (ha) of damaging veld fires (i.e. damaging and catastrophic fires, as described in section 2.5) per annum in the Fynbos Biome

baseline.comment:
Non-Damaging veld fires: Area (ha): 145,200 No.: 1,580
Catastrophic fires: Area: 74,800 ha Number: 420
Based on the 5-year average of 2000 fires/annum covering an area of 220,000ha/annum. (the baseline info)

target.comment:
Non-Damaging veld fires: Area:165,000 ha Number: 1,700
Catastrophic fires: Area: <52,500 (or 30% reduction) Number: <300 (or 30% decrease)
<!--52-->
<!--52-->
The total areas burned (by non-damaging and damaging combined) might not show a significant reduction by the end of the project implementation; however, the socioeconomic consequences left by non-damaging veld fire and those by catastrophic fires are significantly different.

actual.comment: The CSIR is currently busy establishing the amount of area burnt within the Biome during the project period and also 10 years preceding the project. They will also try to differentiate between accidental wildfires and prescribed burns. This will take some time as burn permits are held within Municipalities and not every permit issued resulted in a fire. Results will be available by December 2015

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Capacity built at local level to manage increased incidence and extent of fires

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of FPAs integrated into, and aligned with, the affected municipal structures (including the municipal land use planning, fire brigade and disaster management services).

target.comment: 6 FPAs are aligned with their corresponding municipal structures

actual.comment:
The FPA Toolkit is in its production phase in is incorporating recommendations by stakeholders and partners with regards to FPA alignment. This process is being chaired by Provincial Disaster Management.
The project has started the process of consolidation of smaller FPAs in the Sarah Baartman Municipal Distric in the Eastern Cape to test out the findings and recommendations that are in the toolkit. This will be concluded in December 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of FPAs with the adaptive capacity to effectively manage the risks associated with climate-induced fires

actual.comment: The Greater Cederberg FPA, The Cape Peninsula FPA, the Southern Cape FPA and the 2 pilot site FPAs- Cape Winelands and Greater Overberg, are fully functional and servicing members. The project is planning to amalgamate the 17 FPAs within the 9 local Municipalities in the Sarah Baartman District of the Eastern Cape. This will add an additional FPA

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of wildland fire management staff completing specialized training and/or skills development in adaptation-related fire management technologies

target.comment: 30 (short courses) & 4 (full-time courses)

actual.comment: A Total of 1410 stakeholders have been training in a variety of courses identified by the Capacity Development Working Group. Please see that attached spreadsheet for details

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of FPAs with adequate sustainable financing sources to mitigate the increasing risk of wildfires as a consequence of climate change

actual.comment: The project is aiming to almalgamate the existing smaller FPAs in the Sarah Baartman District of the Eastern Cape and form a District Wide FPA. This will bring the number of FPAs with adequate sustainable financing sources to mitigate the increasing risk of wildfires as a consequence of climate change to 6 in total

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Decision-support and risk management systems for fire management improved

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of FPAs with functional, populated (i.e. data) and networked AFIS field terminals

target.comment: 6 AFIS field terminals installed across the Fynbos Biome

actual.comment: Target achieved

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Coverage (ha) of area where fires are detected, profiled (for risk) and tracked by the FPA AFIS field terminals

target.comment: 4 million ha

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of AWSs recording local weather conditions under a changing climate regime in the high altitude mountain areas of the Fynbos Biome

target.comment: 50 Automated Weather Stations will be in place to measure local weather conditions

actual.comment: Due to the fluctuation of the Rand vs the US Dollar, there are now more funds to purchase 10 additional weather stations. The project extension period is providing the time for these to be installed in gap areas across the biome. Project consultants are working with stakeholders to identify sites, based on operational needs. There are currently a number of low lying areas (as opposed to high altitude areas) that lack accurate real time weather data, which hampers FDI predictions and fire fighting operations.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Average percentage (across all FPAs) of FPA members receiving localised daily fire danger forecasts

target.comment: 80% of paid up Fire Protection Association members in the Fynbos Biome receive local daily fire danger forecasts

actual.comment: All paid up members of 5 FPAs are receiving localised daily fire danger forecasts during the fire season. The Southern Cape FPA is sending this data to their members all year round

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Extent (ha) of the Fynbos Biome with a local landscape level wildfire risk rating that integrates climate change scenarios into the risk assessment

target.comment: 3 million ha of the Fynbos Biome will have a wildfire risk rating

actual.comment: The CSIR is working with each of the 5 established FPAs to map their fire risk. The system they created will be workshopped with FPA managers and staff so that they are able to update it themselves annually and ensure sustainability of the process.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of municipalities (local, district and metropolitan) with climate-based fire risk information for wildlands integrated into the municipal disaster management plans.

target.comment: 6 Municipalities intergrate climate-based fire risk information into their management plans

actual.comment: The attached reports will be submitted to Provincial Disaster Management in order to facilitate the integration of findings into municipal structures. Additionally, the project is investing in the development of the Fynbos Fire Hazard Early Warning Information System Portal, which will be database-driven web-enabled. The intention is to utilise the following services: web service, database service, analytical (mathematics, statistics, optimisation) service, and visualisation (GIS, 2D/3D) service. Interdependences of those services will be designed optimally for use by all stakeholders, including municipalities

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Innovative risk reduction interventions implemented

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage of landowners in the demonstration areas (Southern Cape FPA and Cedarberg FPA) that are paid up members of the FPA, and conform with the FPA rules and regulations

target.comment: 60% of the potential landowners within the 2012 Southern Cape FPA and Cedarberg FPA boundaries are paid up and functional FPA members

actual.comment: Accurate statistics will be gleaned from 5 FPAs by December 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of private landowners in FPAs instituting proactive risk management measures in response to insurance-based incentives

target.comment: 100 private landowners in FPAs respond positively to insurance-based incentives set up by the project

actual.comment:
An ongoing dialogue with SANTAM, and now with Mutual & Federal (together being the two market leaders in short-term insurance), has now secured formal correspondence clarifying the benefits to a landowner of FPA membership, including the incentives offered by insurers to a landowner to join a FPA.
Based on in-field research with FPAs and 5 of the Western Cape FireWise communities, strong consumer and commercial interest has been confirmed for two new or amended existing short-term products: one focused on the emerging market and centered around FireWise communities (homeowner, asset and livestock insurance in a group scheme model, with emphasis on fire, flood and disaster perils), and a second focused on commercial insurance for FPAs themselves. This latter product would provide asset insurance, third party and liability cover, and provide for a certain portion of fire suppression costs a FPA is likely to contract or provide in a season.
An outline business case has been prepared for SANTAM to take to Executive level, showing the potential for these two new (or amended existing) products and pathways for development.
A similar conversation has been opened with Mutual and Federal, and SAFIRE.
Submissions have been provided to the Programme for the Insurance component of the Handbook text.
A successful meeting with Novitas Capital Advisors was held to plan a workshop (for late July) on developing the WildFire & Disaster Trust Fund, and potentially widening the scope to include all forms of disaster (not just wildfire) much like was accomplished for â€˜political riskâ€™ by the South African Special Risk Insurance Association (SASRIA).
A Trust attorney has been approached to advise on the establishment of the WildFire & Disaster Trust Fund.
A presentation to the SAIA Commercial and Personal Lines Technical Committee was delivered (see report below).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of households in the targeted WUI areas that have an improved resilience to outbreaks of climate-induced wildfires

target.comment: 2500 households in the targeted WUI areas that have an improved resilience to outbreaks of climate-induced wildfires

actual.comment: Target achieved

iati-activity.title: Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standard
iati-activity.description: The primary objective of the project is to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions caused by the electricity consumption of household appliances in South Africa

document-link.title: Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standards and Labelling of Appliances in South Africa
Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standard
Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standard

iati-activity.title: Market Transformation
iati-activity.description: Policy and regulatory framework for labels and standards

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Evidence of applicable S&L implementing regulations gazetted and enacted
2.Energy classes and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products included in DoE & DTI action plans
3. Number of institutions audited and capacitated
4. Number of consumers and retailers who are made aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and labels
5.Market Surveillance & Compliance (MSC) procedures adopted and implemented

baseline.comment:
2013: Insufficient or out-dated policy/regulatory framework to implement Standards & Labelling to address the current challenges on energy and electricity.
2013: Labelling specifications and MEPs are unknown.
2013: There are no accredited institutions for testing and enforcement of standards and labels
2013: There is limited awareness amongst consumers and retailers on energy efficiency
2013: No Standards and Labels in place .

target.comment: 1. Policy and regulatory framework for standards and libeling programme 2. Libeling specification and MEPs 3. Strengthened institutional capacity 4. Awareness raising programme developed and implemented Implementation of the market surveilance and compliance regime

actual.comment: With regard to household access to renewable energy efficient technologies, most relevant 2014 milestones were not reached due to governmentâ€™s restructuring, post national elections and governmentâ€™s new approach for an integrated energy planning, which is meant to address all energy carriers and the three objectives of sustainable energy for all on access, renewable and energy efficiency. The Standards and labeling project has also experienced implementation delays due to inadequate government responsiveness on market transformation owing to a lack of agreement on cash disbursement modalities. As a result, the set targets for this project in 2014 were not realized.

target.comment: 1. Policy and regulatory framework for standards and libeling programme 2. Libeling specification and MEPs 3. Strengthened institutional capacity 4. Awareness raising programme developed and implemented Implementation of the market surveilance and compliance regime

actual.comment: here has been a gradual increase in the energy efficiency in the residential sector of listed appliances in the country without regulations. This was largely influenced by compelling trading policies in the European Union (EU) and global advancements in technology. Through the UNDP/GEF support, minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for 10 of the 11 listed appliances were drafted and promulgated, with the exception of electric geysers which is currently being amended to have a higher energy efficiency specification. MEPS for electric water heaters were ultimately set for energy class B, which is a level higher than the level C recommended in the FRIDGE study. These MEPS are planned to be implemented in 2016 and the appliances are projected to reduce electricity demand and GHG emissions by 5.55 TWh and 5.49 million tCO2eq by 2030 [[E14]].

result.title: Objective
result.description: Reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions caused by the electricity consumption of household appliances in South Africa by facilitating a comprehensive transformation of the home appliance market through the introduction of a combination of two regulatory tools Minimum Energy Performance Standards and Information Labels (S&L) and a series of associated awareness-building and monitoring activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
kWh of electricity demand reduction in the residential sector by year 5 of project implementation
Tons of CO2 emissions reduction by year 5 of the project implementation

baseline.comment: The average efficiency of most appliances sold in SA is lower than the previous European class G.

target.comment:
Increase awareness of energy efficiency
Increase market share of high efficient appliances
Reduce electricity demand by 4.41 TWh over the project time.
Reduce CO2 emissions by 4.54 MtCo2 over the project time

actual.comment:
The baseline study concluded that there has been a gradual increase in the energy efficiency of the appliances covered by the project. This increase in performance was largely influenced by policy developments in the EU and by advancements in technology. Appliances that still had potential for improvement were air conditioners, refrigerators and electric water heaters. Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) set for these appliances were projected to reduce electricity demand and GHG emissions by 5.55 TWh and 5.49 million tCO2eq in 2013, respectively.
New MEPS for 10 of the 12 listed appliances were promulgated in November under the National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications (NRCS) technical regulation (VC) 9008. The effective date for enforcement of the regulations is set for February 2016.
New energy performance levels for incandescent lights, which are intended to remove less efficient lights, were enforceable from August 2014.
MEPS for electric water heaters were ultimately set for energy class B, which is a level higher than the level C recommended in the FRIDGE study. A process to amend VC 9006 and incorporate the new MEPS has been initiated in consultation with affected manufacturers.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Policy and regulatory framework for the S&L program: Strengthen structures and mechanisms for appliance energy efficiency standards and labels (S&L)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Evidence of applicable S&L implementing regulations gazetted and enacted
Evidence that relevant regulations are disseminated to key industry stakeholders

baseline.comment: Insufficient policy/regulatory framework to implement S&L programme

target.comment: Policy/ institutional/ regulatory framework on energy efficient appliances is gazetted and enacted into law under the National Energy Act by end of 2013

actual.comment:
The existing regulatory framework under the NRCS remains relevant for setting up minimum energy performance standards.
Regulations introducing new energy performance standards for all listed appliances are now in place. These include VC 9008 for all listed white goods and audio-visual equipment, VC8043 which set performance standards for incandescent lights, and VC9006 for electric water heaters.
VC 9008 is already enforceable for standby power and the enforcement date for the remainder of the appliances under this VC will be from February 2016.
VC 8043 on incandescent lamps has been enforced since August 2014.
VC 9006 is undergoing amendments to increase the MEPS to energy class B as recommended by the engineering and economic impact study for electric geysers conducted in 2014.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Define labeling specifications and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products considered by the DoE & DTI for S&L regulation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Energy classes and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products included in DoE & DTI action plan

baseline.comment: Labelling specifications and MEPS are unknown

target.comment: By 2012, reach an agreement with stakeholders on energy classes and MEPS requirements for the 12 products included in DoE & DTI action plan

actual.comment:
MEPS threshold for 11 appliances have been defined and have been discussed with the affected manufacturers and other industry players.
The promulgated energy classes:
- Air conditioners: Energy efficiency rating of Class B
- Audio and video equipment standby power of 1W or less
- Large electric ovens: Efficiency rating of Class B
- Small/ Medium electric ovens: Energy Class A
- Refrigerators: Energy efficiency rating of Class B
- Freezers: Energy efficiency rating of Class C
- Dishwashers: Energy efficiency rating of Class A
- Washing Machines: Energy efficiency rating of Class A.
- Washer-dryer combinations: Efficiency rating of Class A
- Tumbleâ€“dryers: Energy efficiency rating of Class D
- Electric geysers: Energy efficiency rating of Class B
While the energy class for electric geysers has been agreed with manufacturers, the process of amending the geyser technical regulations is still underway.
Work on finalising the label design and developing a label guideline that will be used in printing labels for the different appliances has begun. This work will culminate with a launch of the label in September 2015.
The Working Group on Specifications and Labelling is currently considering the recent announcement by the European Commission to ditch the A+ grading and revert to the A â€“ G grading. The South African label and MEPS threshold are based on the EU directives and changes in the EU energy efficiency grading system will require changes to the label design and the testing standards may need to be reviewed.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Strengthen the capacity of institutions and individuals involved in the S&L program.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of institutions audited and capacities upgraded
Number of staff trained

target.comment:
Accreditation of testing facilities (public & private) and enforcement institution
Adaptation of International/EU test procedures to the South African climatic and usage conditions when needed

actual.comment:
A survey on the readiness of test facilities was conducted during the second quarter of 2014. Results of the readiness survey indicated that all South African test facilities were upgrading their facilities in anticipation of the new energy efficiency testing requirements.
The South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) was, however, ahead in terms of required test equipment and staff readiness to test. Gerotek and Test Africa, two private sector testing labs, indicated that they would need assistance from the project for gap analysis and staff training.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Awareness raising campaign for standards and labels, targeting manufacturers, distributors, retailers and end-users.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Consumers and retailers become more aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and labels and retailers via sampling and surveys

target.comment: At least 50% of consumers and retailers contacted (within the sample group) become more aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and labels and retailers provide evidence of marketing efforts to support the scheme

actual.comment:
The services of the DoE communications service provider could not be procured during the second and third quarters of 2014. A request was later made by DoE to obtain UNDPâ€™s assistance with procurement of an S&L project communications service provider for the development and implementation of the project communications plan. This request was, however, halted on DoEâ€™s subsequent instruction in September 2014.
The DoEâ€™s communications terms of reference were not approved by the DoE Bid Adjudication Committee. Instead, a recommendation to prioritise activities for the first quarter of 2015 was made. The finalisation of the label design, development of the label guideline and launch of the label were also prioritised for 2015.
DoE requested UNDP to resume the procurement of a communications company in May 2015, a process that is now underway.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Implementation of S&L Market Surveillance & Compliance (MSC) regime to ensure energy performance standards is met

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
MSC procedures adopted and implemented
Number of models/product excluded from the S&L programme

target.comment: Minimum number of products sold in the market (ratio TBD for each appliance type) which comply with the S&L requirements

actual.comment: Negotiations with the UK National Measurement Office to assist improvement in the monitoring and enforcement regime of the NRCS did not materialise and NRCS has commenced with self-assessment. NRCS's assessment will be presented in the next PSC meeting.

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: Development of Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) capacity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Skilled South African professionals trained on M&E of energy projects

target.comment: All those skilled South African professionals trained demonstrate appropriate level of knowledge

actual.comment: Work for this Outcome has not commenced. However, the project underwent a mid-term review during the second quarter of 2015, and a management response to the mid-term review was prepared and uploaded to the UNDP ERC website. The MTR devoted considerable attention to the issue of professional training and capacity needs of stakeholders.

result.title: Output 1.1
result.description: Review of existing policies and regulations. Provide feedback and advice for any corrective or new action to be taken to reduce project risks.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of stakeholders engaged in consultations
Ensure any other programme (energy or environmental) is identified to avoid confusion amongst consumers

baseline.comment:
S&L Action plan developed by DoE & DTI
DoE to introduce law to allow for MEPS
(The MEPS are currently regulated under the NRCS Act, hence introduction lf law by DoE will not be necessary.)
DTI plans to develop enforcement regulations

target.comment:
Majority of stakeholders review S&L implementation regulations & approve final proposal of energy classes and MEPS thresholds.
S&L program extended to new set of products

actual.comment:
The findings of the GIZ study that South Africa has adequate policies and regulatory framework to support the introduction of energy efficiency in household appliances were accepted by the PSC with a proviso that new policies for incentives may need to be considered in the future.
Manufacturers and importers of listed white goods and audio-visual equipment were consulted in the development of test procedures and the setting of MEPS and related regulations.
A consultative process with manufacturers was followed in determining the energy efficient class for electric geysers; three workshops were held with manufacturers, leading to the agreement of energy class B.

result.title: Output 1.2
result.description: Evaluation of financial incentives such as the rebate program operated by the Eskom DSM for purchasing efficient appliances. Development of new financial incentives if needed.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of existing rebate programs

target.comment: Increase in market share of efficient appliances

actual.comment:
The project-supported incentives study recommended four incentive schemes:
- A standard offer for LED lights
- Subsidisation of electric geysers
- A swap programme for refrigerators
- A rebate system for purchasing energy efficient appliances, above the MEPS
In addition to the above, the study further recommended that government needs to lead by example and should set up a procurement policy that will compel state organs to purchase energy efficient appliances and equipment.
Terms of reference for the review of the proposed incentives and the development of a business case, funding model and running a pilot to test the viability of the incentives schemes have been prepared.

result.title: Output 2.1
result.description: Conduct market and engineering analysis for the products selected for S&L regulation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Cost benefits analysis conducted for the 12 products selected for S&L regulation
Number of market research and industry studies conducted.
Market transformation benefits demonstrated to stakeholders.

target.comment: Propose energy classes and MEPS thresholds applicable for the South African market.

actual.comment:
A study on the engineering and economic impacts of introducing energy efficient electric geysers led by the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Linkd, a service provider commissioned by the project, concluded that the efficiency of electric geysers can be improved to energy class B. This was a level higher than the energy class C recommended during the FRIDGE study.
The study further concluded that the cost for the incremental improvements on geysers will be about R300.00 (for increasing the insulation thickness of a 150 litre geyser to 50 mm).
A consultative process to amend the compulsory specifications for geysers has commenced.

result.title: Output 2.2
result.description: Adopt labeling specifications and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products selected for S&L regulations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Labelling energy classes and MEPS adopted

target.comment:
Implementation of energy classes and MEPS thresholds
Agreement with stakeholders on schedule to phase out inefficient appliances

actual.comment:
The technical regulation (VC 9008), which is guided by SANS 941 covering 10 of the listed appliances and includes the use of the label, was promulgated in November 2014. The effective date for the enforcement of the regulations was May 29 2014 (for standby power) and the effective date for the other appliances under VC9008 will be enforced from February 2016.
The technical regulations for lamps VC8043, which is intended to remove inefficient electric lamps from the market, are now in force.

result.title: Output 3.1
result.description: Strengthen institutions (testing facilities, enforcement institution...)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of testing facilities audited
Number of testing facilities upgraded
Number of testing facilities accredited
Accreditation of enforcement institution

target.comment:
Upgrade the existing facilities
Ensure test facilities are operational, sufficient & available for compliance checking.

actual.comment:
SABS had its test facility audited by Intertek, a UK-based test facility which was appointed as a SABS technology partner. Intertek assessed the extent of the SABS testing facilities upgrade requirements and has assisted with the design of the air-conditioner test chamber.
Intertek also assisted SABS to meet training requirement for standby power, leading to its accreditation in November 2014.
An agreement to extend the projectâ€™s assistance to the other two test facilities, Gerotek and Test Africa, was reached in May 2015. A process to appoint a technology partner for Gerotek and Test Africa is underway.
Test Africa has already been accredited for standby power.

result.title: Output 3.2
result.description: Strengthen employee skills

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Necessary intergovernmental forums established to ensure coordinate effort
Number of employees trained

target.comment:
Train the required number of people based on sales & number of units to be tested per year.
Train all staff involved on testing and enforcement on accreditation requirements & constraints
Adoption of conversion factors for testing considering the South African conditions
Train the required number of inspectors for trade inspections and compliance checking

actual.comment:
Intertek also trained SABS staff on refrigeration, dish washers and standby power. This training forms part of the train-the-trainer programme, in which trained senior staff members conduct in-house training to their colleagues.
One SABS staff has also undertaken training on air conditioners and has visited other test facilities to gather technical information on the design of the air conditioner test chamber, pressure vessel and suction box.
Four NRCS staff members have since undertaken a study visit to South Korea. The visit had the following objectives:
(i) To introduce NRCS staff/inspectors to energy efficiency mandatory requirements and product labelling.
(ii) To familiarise inspectors with energy efficiency test procures and verification of compliance.
(iii) To observing and participate in market surveillance and enforcement activities to ensure compliance with energy efficiency regulations.
Participants visited the KTL Test Facility, the South Korean regulator KEMCO and a manufacturing plant (LG).
Two workshops with local and international experts on economic incentives and compliance enforcement were held on August 27 and 28 2015 respectively. Participants included the representatives from NRCS, CLASP, SEAD, University of Pretoria, National Treasury, the DTI, DoE and S&L project managers from Ghana, Kenya, India and China.
A four-day study mission to the UK was undertaken in July (July 28 â€“ 31). Participants to the study mission were selected from the S&L Project Steering Committee (PSC) and Working Groups established under the PSC. The selection was guided by the missionâ€™s objectives and the areas of interest that would be covered during the mission. Based on these criteria, the following institutions participated in the mission:
(i) National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications
(ii) United Nations Development Programme
(iii) South African Bureau of Standards
(iv) Department of Trade Industry
(v) Department of Environment
(vi) Department of Energy
(vii) Eskom
The study mission had the following objectives:
(i) To introduce participants to policies supportive of the S&L project.
(ii) To discuss potential incentives for manufacturers and consumers.
(iii) To discuss and share experiences on monitoring and enforcement regimes supportive of the S&L project.
(iv) To identify areas of future collaboration on key project areas.

result.title: Output 4.1
result.description: Test and adopt Label design

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of dissemination activities offered to consumers and retailers
Number of consumers (particularly low incomes) and retailers covered by dissemination activities

target.comment: At least 50% of consumers and retailers contacted (within the sample group) are able to understand the meaning of the label and its benefits

actual.comment: A service provider, The Guild, has been appointed for the design and development of a label guideline, and the first design draft has been circulated to the project's Specifications and Labelling Working Group for discussion.

result.title: Output 4.2
result.description: Develop communication campaign towards manufacturers, importers, distributors, retailers and consumers about appliancesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ energy efficiency

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of dissemination activities offered to each category
Number of people covered by dissemination activities

target.comment:
A statistically relevant sample of households will be drawn on to determine the market penetration & effectiveness of the project
Ensure consumers distinguish between MEPS & extra financial benefits of exceeding MEPS voluntarily.
At minimum, the staff of top 10 manufacturers, distributors are aware about S&L programmes

actual.comment:
The project experienced serious delays in the appointment of a communications company to assist with development and implementation of a communications plan, and this has affected the anticipated awareness raising on the imminent implementation of the MEPS and the consumer benefits of using energy efficient appliances. These delays have stemmed from a lack of agreement on the cash transfer modalities between DoE and UNDP.
In August 2015, DoE finally formally requested UNDP to assist with the procurement of the communications company and is in the process of appointing SABS as project fund administrator. The agreement between DoE and SABS has been approved by the DoE Director-General and forwarded to SABS for counter-signature.
The procurement of a communications company through UNDP has begun and two companies have been shortlisted and invited to present before a preferred bidder is announced.

result.title: Output 4.3
result.description: Develop and deliver training programs for distributors and retailers staff.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of trainings delivered.
Numbers of trainers involved

target.comment: Retailers and distributors able to deliver S&L message to end-users

actual.comment: The delays in the procurement of a communications company have affected the training of retail staff on energy efficiency and the use of the energy efficiency label.

result.title: Output 5.1
result.description: Development of MSC procedures for regulated products

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: MSC procedures adopted

target.comment:
Dissemination of MSC procedures
Train NRCS staff on MSC activities and compliance procedures

actual.comment: NRCS is conducting a self-audit of its capacity requirements. Its audit report is due imminently and will be presented to the next (October 2015) PSC meeting.

result.title: Output 5.2
result.description: Integration of product energy performance compliance checking with local manufacturers and country pre-import inspections.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: MSC procedures implemented

target.comment: Develop database of S&L products

actual.comment:
The baseline determination process to ascertain the projected electricity demand reduction and related GHG emission reductions resulting from improvements in energy efficiency of listed appliances commenced in the third quarter of 2014.
The baseline project went through a consultative process with key stakeholders to determine the database use cases.
The second phase of project activities focused on developing the database specifications and methodology for populating the database. This led to the development of database schema/diagram listing required data for the 12 appliances.
Training on the use and querying of the database was conducted in February 2015, following the handover of the database to DoE. DoE will provide further access to the database by other government institutions as may be required.
A workshop with manufacturers to discuss requirements for annual submission of appliance data was held in February 2015.
Energy data collected during the baseline study was used to calculate energy and GHG emission reduction.

result.title: Output 6.1
result.description: Replication of S&L program for new set of products

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Work plan to replicate the S&L for a new set of products

target.comment: Extend S&L programme for other appliances and equipment

actual.comment: No activities were implemented under this output in this reporting period.

result.title: Output 6.2
result.description: Implementation of Monitoring and Evaluation methodology for S&L programs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of staff trained on M&E of S&L programs
Launching of metering campaigns and data collection studies

baseline.comment: Eskom has developed expertise on metering campaigns

target.comment:
Make M&E activities part of the whole process
Record lessons learnt

actual.comment: No activities were implemented under this output in this reporting period.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent in which the public sector institutional capacity has been strengthened 2. Extent in which local knowledge has been expanded to improve governance and performance of the public sector 3. Progress made on institutionalization of key support programmes to improve service delivery and good governance 4. Extent to which government has been supported to reposition the public sector 5. Number of training modules developed & facilitators trained at the KZN Academy 6. progress made on the production of the KZN Human Development Index Report 7. Extent to which KZN province M&E institutional capacity has been enhanced to improve governance & service delivery

baseline.comment: â€¢ 8.8% decrease in average citizen satisfaction between 2009-2012 due to uneven access & low quality of services; & limited capacity of oversight bodies. â€¢ 73 % of eligible voters voted in national elections in 2014, & 57% in local government elections in 2011 â€¢ Uneven access & quality of services across 3 spheres of government due to inadequate provincial institutional capacity for a developmental state; & inadequate monitoring & evaluation capacity & systems to produce evidence-based human development information to inform strategic planning processes & policies

target.comment: 1. Curriculum/ training materials on RBM/M&E, ethics, integrity & accountability, anti-corruption, developed for KwaZulu-Natal Public Service Academy

actual.comment: The Regional Service Centre approached for technical support, and they have agreed to develop the material starting in 2015

target.comment:
â€¢ Parliament -Interagency Capacity Building & support programme developed & implemented â€¢ Legislatures Consultation: Migration â€¢ EAD Desk Review Report â€¢ IEC Support Programme (2015-2019) â€¢ Programme Implementation Preparation Manager appointed to institutionalize the programme ( resource mobilization, key stakeholder identification and management, facilitate recruitment of required expertise, establish office, 2016 AWP etc.)
â€¢ KZN Programme of Support ( Prodoc 2015-2017/8) â€¢ Provincial public sector capacity needs assessment & Integrated HRD Report ,& Professional Support Programme for â€¢ â€¢ Provincial and Local Government Managers, aligned to the PGDP & NDP â€¢ RBM training material ,training of facilitators/trainees

actual.comment: A provincial Results Based Management/Monitoring and Evaluation capacity assessment was undertaken to inform the Provincial Public Service Training Academy future training scope and approach on RBM/M&E. The assessment recommended a need to for a comprehensive approach to RBM/M&E capacity development and system development that includes the Premierâ€™s Office, provincial government departments, and municipalities. The RBM curriculum and training material for long and short courses has been developed and approved by the UNDP and Academy. The planned training of 40 officials could not take place due to the fact the province wanted to allign the training with the national departmentâ€™s planning, monitoring and evaluation training framework that has recently been developed. The UNDP and the Academy held a meeting on 19 November 2015, and agreed that the training will take place in the first quarter of 2016. Training material on ethics, integrity and anti-corruption has also been developed, and it was initiallay planned to be conducted in November 2015 targetting 40 officials, and has been defferred to February 2016. Three meetings were held with the province this year. The 2015-2017 project document has been developed and finalised, and agreed to by UNDP and the ACADEMY, and will be delivered on a cost sharing basis (an estimated total amount of $190 166). Provision has been made for three outputs to be delivered during this period, viz. Training and capacity development on RBM and anti corruption and ethics (targeting 40 officials in each respective programme); African leadership programme that will target 96 officials in the province, and the development of the HRD and professional support programme

iati-activity.title: UNCRPD Disability
iati-activity.description: Accelerating the Implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) in South Africa
iati-activity.participating-org: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Extent to which institutional capacity has been expanded to disability policy, programmes and allocation of resources

baseline.comment: 2013: Inadequate institutional capacity to plan and implement disability policy, programmes and allocation of resources.

target.comment: Institutional capacity developed in the area of data collection and management, and disability monitoring mechanisms

actual.comment: The UNDP-led UN-Government joint Programme on Rights of People with Disability (PRPD) has succeeded in advocating for the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of People with Disability. Government officials across all 3 spheres of government and the South African Human Rights Commission are now participating in the National Disability Rights Machinery.

target.comment: National Disability Rights Policy (NDRP) developed and approved by Cabinet

actual.comment: The final draft of the National Disability Rights Policy (NDRP) has been submitted to Cabinet for approval. The Policy will ensure that SA honours its obligations under the International Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, to which it is a signatory [[E19]] UNDP supported the DSD to develop a disability rights monitoring and evaluation framework which is being used to track progress in eradicating inequalities and reducing poverty among people with disabilities and their families. Aspects of the M&E indicator matrix, in-depth analysis of disability disaggregation of the NDP as well as elements of the Cost of Disability research were used in the drafting of the Policy. The Department of Higher Education and Training (DHET) is also making extensive use of the statistical information generated by this joint programme to develop a disability mainstreaming policy for all post-school education and training programmes to addressing disability within post-school institutions.

iati-activity.title: Accountability and Citizenry
iati-activity.description: Enhanced Public Accountability and Community Engagement

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Extent to which legislative capacity & knowledge base for oversight & participation in global fora has been expanded
2. Extent to which national & regional institutional capacity has been strengthened and knowledge exchange expanded to improve on electoral management, and citizen participation
3. Extent to which the CPSI institutional capacity has been enhanced; its knowledge networks have been expanded; & innovation has been mainstreamed in the public sector

baseline.comment:
â€¢ 5th Parliament Strategic Objectives: Strengthen Oversight & Accountability, Enhanced Public Involvement, Deepening Engagement in International Fora, Strengthening Legislative Capacity
â€¢ Declining Voter-Turn out since 1994, and increasing IEC support to regional electoral processes
â€¢ CPSI mandate to identify, support and nurture innovation in the public service, with a view to improve service delivery, and provide the public sector with independent, diverse and forward-looking research and advice on innovative service delivery with a specific focus on governmentâ€™s priorities.

target.comment: 1. Interagency Parliament Capacity Development Programme developed & initiated 2. A comprehensive programme of support to the IEC which will include a sub-regional electoral hub in place including a resource mobilization plan

actual.comment: Due to the 2014 National and Provincial Elections, and appointment of new MPS, it was a challenge to institutionalise a process to develop support programme to both the Parliament and the Independent Electoral Committee.

target.comment: â€¢ Parliament -Interagency Capacity Building & support programme developed & implemented â€¢ Legislatures Consultation: Migration â€¢ EAD Desk Review Report â€¢ IEC Support Programme (2015-2019) â€¢ Programme Implementation Preparation Manager appointed to institutionalize the programme ( resource mobilization, key stakeholder identification and management, facilitate recruitment of required expertise, establish office, 2016 AWP etc.)

actual.comment: A concept paper was developed, a meeting held with the Secretary of Parliament in September and identifed areas include capacity building of staff, and that of portfolio committeess, especially targetting and starting with the Chairpersons. The 2015-2019 strategic priorities and plan was shared with the UNDP, and a joint programme that include support to parliamentâ€™s particaipation effectively on SDGS and climate change issues developed and discussed in the the SCF Results Grouo meeting in December 2015. Following another UNDP meeting with the Speaker of Parliament in November, UNDP asked to provide technical and resource support to a high level panel that will look into the impact of legislation over the last 21 years. An MOU between UNDP and Parliament drafted, which will include the support to the Speakers Forum high level pnal, and other joint areas identfied for implementation in 2016. Support was ready to be provided to the hosting of the international conference on statelenss that was co hosted by Parliament, but UNHCR HQ steeped in to provide the necessary resources.Following the signing of the MOU, and the request from IEC for support, a Logframe that captures all areas of support was developed by the Country Office, and endorsed by the IEC. Following the endorsement of the Logframe, the CO approached HQs for a technical support to develop a project document on support to the IEC. A UNDP Project Document Formulation Mission was deployed to Pretoria, South Africa for five working days, from 13-17 April, to support the Country Office in developing the project document for the planned new electoral assistance project that intends to provide support to the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) and other relevant stakeholders within the civil society, the government and the educational sector. The EAD Review Report was produced, together with the Mission report. The project document has been developed and submitted to IEC for review, with the desk top re
